Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Prepare and maintain financial records accurately.
Situation2: An external auditor has just requested specific financial statements for an immediate review.
Story: It was 2 a.m. when my phone buzzed, jolting me awake. On the other end, my best friend’s voice trembled with tears—her father had just been rushed to the hospital. She needed me to listen, to be present, to help her hold together the pieces of her world. I sat up, heart pounding, trying to offer comfort, but my laptop screen glowed accusingly from across the room. Just an hour earlier, I’d received an urgent email from the external auditor: they needed the quarterly financial statements by sunrise. As an accountant, accuracy and timeliness were non-negotiable. My mind raced, torn between the spreadsheet’s demands and my friend’s pain. She sobbed, asking if I could stay on the line, and I could hear the expectation in her voice. At the same time, the clock ticked down, each minute lost making the audit deadline feel more impossible. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, my loyalty and professionalism pulling me in opposite directions, and I didn’t know which part of me to let down.
